element.name: Dunsany Cross by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

long-description.p: This small cross probably dates from the beginning of the 17th century. On one face it has a Crucifixion set within a recessed cross-shaped panel. This is surmounted by a winged ox, the symbol of St Luke. This cross is mounted on a large rectangular base which contains two bullauns, each about 20cm diameter. It is almost directly opposite the entrance to Dunsany Castle.

Dunsany Castle and Demesne are situated in the townland of Dunsany (Dun Samhnaigh or Dun Samhna), between the historic town of Trim, with Ireland's largest castle (King John's Castle or simply Trim Castle, a former Dunsany holding) and the large village of Dunshaughlin on one of the country's main routes, in County Meath.
The Castle is the longest occupied home and one of the oldest continuously inhabited buildings in Ireland, though the Lords of Dunsany have suffered on a couple of occasions, such as when the ninth Lord, elected by the Catholic peers of Ireland to assert their loyalty to the State, was imprisoned for several years in Dublin Castle before being sent to Connaught. While his family died on the journey, he was reinstated at the time of the Restoration. Later, the tenth Lord fought for James II at the Battle of the Boyne and was outlawed but the estates were restored to his successor after the Treaty of Limerick.
The cache is a micro container please rehide it well to prevent muggles from discovering its location.

ul.li:
2010-06-17T19:00:00Z : Found it by Spark_ie
Quick find while caching in the area after work [:)] TFTC, Spark_ie

2010-05-18T19:00:00Z : Found it by Serapis
A quick find on my way from Kells to Waterford. The road was quite busy here and it took me a few minutes to reteieve and replace. TFTC. Serapis.

2010-04-11T19:00:00Z : Found it by merann
Took a few minutes to find this one. Co-ords had us on the other side of the road but we couldn't see anywhere it could be, once we crossed over the cache was soon found. Good hide! SL. TFTC, Merann.

2010-03-27T19:00:00Z : Found it by Fjon
Nice easy find - thanks!

2010-03-05T20:00:00Z : Found it by Blue Jay 59
Found this on my way to Cavan on Friday morning. Used to come to Dunsany when I was a child, so brought back memories. See you can do tours of the castle now, will have to return for that [:D] TFTC Blue Jay 59 #235

wpt.name: GC23KEB
wpt.desc: Dunsany Cross by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Dunsany Cross
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This small cross probably dates from the beginning of the 17th century. On one face it has a Crucifixion set within a recessed cross-shaped panel. This is surmounted by a winged ox, the symbol of St Luke. This cross is mounted on a large rectangular base which contains two bullauns, each about 20cm diameter. It is almost directly opposite the entrance to Dunsany Castle.

Dunsany Castle and Demesne are situated in the townland of Dunsany (Dun Samhnaigh or Dun Samhna), between the historic town of Trim, with Ireland's largest castle (King John's Castle or simply Trim Castle, a former Dunsany holding) and the large village of Dunshaughlin on one of the country's main routes, in County Meath.
The Castle is the longest occupied home and one of the oldest continuously inhabited buildings in Ireland, though the Lords of Dunsany have suffered on a couple of occasions, such as when the ninth Lord, elected by the Catholic peers of Ireland to assert their loyalty to the State, was imprisoned for several years in Dublin Castle before being sent to Connaught. While his family died on the journey, he was reinstated at the time of the Restoration. Later, the tenth Lord fought for James II at the Battle of the Boyne and was outlawed but the estates were restored to his successor after the Treaty of Limerick.

The Cache

The cache is a micro container please rehide it well to prevent muggles from discovering its location.





Windsockers
